review_blob: 500ml bottle from Sainsburys, poured into tulip glass, sampled at room temperature. Very dark with red tinge, fairly tight head, estery aromas with tinned prunes and roast barley. Big mouthfeel, with lots of fruity, caramelly malts and Christmas pud, balanced by an almost stout-like bitterness, giving a long, satisfying finish: a mighty brew that deserves wider recognition.

On cask at Tennents Bar, Glasgow, 15/08/2014. Amber, slightly hazy (which I dont mind), thick white head through use of sparkler, good lacing. Nice aroma of sugared grapefruit, with some yeastiness. Taste of sultanas and glace cherries, with grapefruit hoppiness; full-bodied. This ale is a favourite of mine, and on this occasion was exceptional.

Cask at The Merchant, Glasgow, 4th August 2014. Deep tawny brown, bubbly head which diminishes quickly, minimal lacing. Aroma of caramel malts, no discernible hops. Flavour is all malt: chocolate-coated toffee and nuts from the high proportion of dark malts. Very full bodied and somewhat sticky, but not cloying. A good dark ale, but too strong and rich to be described as a 60/-.

Poured into pint Nonic glass, at cellar temperature. Deep russet, with medium white head, some lacing. Aroma of malt with only light hops, carried through to the flavour, with a hint of dessert apple. Full bodied and malty sweet, perhaps due to high mashing temperature. A very British beer!

Decanted into oversize jug, to de-carbonate and concentrate aromas, before pouring into Nonic pint glass. Said aroma is superb sweet n sour malt n hops, which diminishes somewhat when poured into glass. Dense ivory white head, with some lacing. Flavour is initially hop-dominated, with toffee apple malt coming through gradually: a bitter ale in the classic Yorkshire style.

330ml bottle, lightly chilled, poured into tulip glass.
Deep golden, with medium white head, some lacing.
Aroma of sweet fruit salad, with grapefruit shining through.
Hops dominate flavour, the malts struggling perhaps due to relatively high percentage of wheat compared to barley malt: as a result, body is somewhat thin, but still fairly well balanced.
Overall, typical of the style, and very drinkable.

Cask fresh on at Drum & Monkey, Glasgow, 23/7/14.
Light malt and floral hop aroma, dense white head reflecting somewhat high carbonation of first pint served from cask; hence, good lacing.
Fine balance of biscuity malt and light hoppiness, good body for its gravity, with a mouthfeel suggesting a stronger ale; reminds me of a good pint of Theakstons Best Bitter.
